title: How is Hermione Granger a strong female character? - Quora

response.answer_text: She is a strongly-written character and she’s female. In a rational world, that should be enough. I frankly would prefer if that phrase wasn’t often synonymous with “bitchy and condescending to male characters while always being depicted as right for being so”, something Hermione is at times guilty of, but at least it’s more she’s a teenage girl and teenage girls can be bitchy just like teenage boys can be dim, and she grows out of it. Unlike a lot of “strong females” who ARE just bitchy and condescending, there’s never any doubt that Hermione is smart, devoted to her friends, and has her own doubts, insecurities, and flaws that aren’t just tacked on to give the authors something to point to (ie “But she THINKS she’s plain!” while it’s clear in text the character isn’t.) Hermione’s strong points are relevant to the plot and make sense for her character, and her flaws are also important and they aren’t (in the books, at least) blissfully excused because she’s a Strong Female Character. They’re genuine FLAWS. She rises above them or learns to moderate them, while still being smart and supportive of her friends and helping with the main plot. A strongly written character does that.
As opposed to many plots that add in a girl only for the sake of love interests and emotional things, Hermione plays here part in the story, and it’s a big part.
